Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Hiroto Kameyama of University of California, San Diego to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at Ehime University in Ehime, Japan. The project title is "(Re)investigation of Wolbachia Infections in Wild Japanese Populations of Drosophila bifasciata." The host scientist is Dr. Masayoshi Watada.

In 1969, Dr. Hiroshi Ikeda investigated the occurrence of "sex-ratio" females in wild populations of Drosophila bifasciata in Japan. "Sex-ratio" or SR females have been shown to kill XY zygotes in early developmental stages, producing a strong bias toward female offspring. Later investigations showed that the Wolbachia-infected D. bifasciata induce male deaths during embryonic development, and further analyses illustrated some of the fundamental mechanisms of selective male killings. The project re-investigates the frequency of "sex-ratio" females in three islands of Japan (Hokkaido, Honshu, and Shikoku) almost half a century after the initial survey and tests for an association with Wolbachia infection in any SR females.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the project in Japan gives American scientists access to researchers and resources in Japan; building bridges between American institutions and Japanese researchers. In addition, the samples of various Drosophila species collected from the three islands will be made available to the international scientific community through Ehime Fly. Finally, it assesses the relationship between what is discovered with a model organism such as Drosophila, and a widespread endosymbiotic bacteria, Wolbachia, under laboratory conditions with what occurs in the wild, and in doing so, bear on the ability to generalize from the laboratory to the natural world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
My project looked to collaborate with Dr. Masayoshi Watada of Ehime University to investigate the occurrence of the “Sex-Ratio” or SR trait in wild Japanese populations of Drosophila bifasciata. The SR trait was discovered by Buzzati-Traverso (1941) and has shown to kill XY zygotes in early developmental stages, producing a strong bias toward female offspring. In 1969, Hiroshi Ikeda investigated the occurrence of SR females in wild populations of Drosophila bifasciata in Japan and recently, in 2000, Hurst et al. showed that the SR condition in D. bifasciata could be created by infection of the Wolbachia bacteria. A closely related species, D. tsukubaenensis, was then later described, leading to question if the previous study by Ikeda may have misidentified some of the samples.  Thus, to investigate the current frequency of the SR trait in Japanese D. bifasciata, wild Drosophila were caught and investigated for Wolbachia infections.

The first sampling trip to Mt. Ishizuchi, Ehime (6/18/13) yielded only fifteen small black Drosophilae amongst 6,000+ other Drosophila not of interest. Sequencing data showed that of the fifteen, fourteen were Scaptodrosophila coracina and one was D. tsukubaensis. The presence of D. tsukubaensis at Mt. Ishizuchi confirmed our suspicions that Ikeda’s study may have misidentified these flies as D. bifasciata. Seventeen small black female flies were captured in the next sampling trip to Mt. Daisen, Tottori (7/3-7/7). Through DNA analysis, five of the flies were determined to be D. bifasciata and nine were D. tsukubaensis, proving the cohabitance of these two species and the inability to discriminate if not by DNA sequencing. No flies tested positive for Wolbachia.

The last trip to Aomori (7/12-7/17) was separated into two localities; Mt. Hakkoda and Yachi Onsen. This trip was the most fruitful with 31 black female flies at Yachi and 45 at Mt. Hakkoda. To our relief, the majority of the black flies were identified as D. bifasciata; 81% (25) at Yachi and 73% (33) at Mt. Hakkoda. The other flies fell into three other clades; D. imaii and two unknown (perhaps undescribed) species. Furthermore, one female from Yachi onsen and four from Mt. Hakkoda tested positive for Wolbachia infection.

Without the ability for DNA identification 40+ years ago, 4 out of 45 Mt. Hakkoda specimens would have indicated an infection rate of about 9%, very similar to Ikeda’s initial results. However, with the recent ease of DNA sequencing and identification, the Wolbachia infections tell a different story. All five specimens that tested positive for Wolbachia belong to one of the unknown species. With only 10 female specimens of this particular species caught, 50% were infected with Wolbachia. Accordingly, in all 77 D. bifasciata that were tested for Wolbachia, none showed any infection or the SR trait.

My duration abroad in Japan was very successful with lots of fieldwork, identifying species and infections in the laboratory, and making foreign professional and social connections. The project possibly yielded two novel Drosophila species and one with a Wolbachia infection of 50%. These findings are further evidence of the importance of conserving and studying Japan’s ecosystem. Although it is commonly believed that Drosophila are one of the most taxonomically studied organisms, there are much more to learn about this genus. I hope that my findings will help to draw global interest in Japan’s Drosophila research and improve Japan’s scientific community and collaborations with other countries.
